Once the nonverbal expression of disgust has occurred, this acknowledgment would be necessary to maintain genuineness. It can be done in a way that does not reject or judge the person who is the client. B is incorrect because it fails to accept the person. C is incorrect because the client will probably be aware of the reaction, even if the therapist suppresses her own knowledge of it. This approach would likely weaken the therapist's credibility with the client. D is incorrect for the same reason that C is incorrect.

This answer describes the technique of partializing and prioritizing, an effective way to help clients in crisis to overcome the feeling of being overwhelmed. A is incorrect because you do not have enough information from the question to know if this client's reaction is within normal limits. For example, this client may be having this reaction because of an underlying personality disorder or because of a history of panic attacks (possibly indicated by the fear of going crazy). A would not be an appropriate response if these conditions applied. However, B would be an appropriate response under a wide variety of conditions. C is incorrect because you don't have enough information to know that medications might be needed. Not all clients who feel confused and anxious when under stress need to be referred for medications. D is incorrect because this kind of exploratory, interpretive therapy is not the best approach when clients are in crisis. A structured, supportive approach and directive role for the therapist would be better.

The client needs to know that legal advice is not something that a marriage and family therapist can offer, but he also needs to know what an MFT can offer that might be helpful in his troubled family situation. A and B are incorrect because they involve giving legal or financial advice. These functions are not within an MFT's scope of practice. D is incorrect because the client may need to see both an attorney and an MFT, not necessarily just one or the other.

Your pre-existing relationship with your individual client would create an unbalanced set of relationships. His wife would be new to you but your relationship with him would be well established. You would be going into these sessions knowing Bob's perspective on his wife, but not knowing her perspective on Bob. All of this would interfere with your ability to help Bob accomplish his purpose of resolving the money issue between him and his wife. A and B are incorrect for the reason that C is correct. D is incorrect because, even though Bob's request might be a resistance, you don't have enough information from the vignette to assume that this is the case.

Giving such advice is based on your familiarity with the limitations of your scope of practice. It addresses the issue of dual relationships without giving medication advice per se. B is incorrect because it involves giving medical advice, specifically, it involves the prescription of medications. C is incorrect because the husband is in a dual relationship with his wife, regardless of your judgment about his objectivity. Besides, it would likely be impractical to disrupt the flow of your therapeutic work with your client in order to have sufficient meetings with the husband and with the couple to make the judgment called for in answer C. D is incorrect because, even though it is not within an MP T's scope of practice to prescribe, dispense or administer medications, that doesn't mean that a marriage and family therapist may not address issues related to medications.

The requested service is within an MFT's scope of practice, but it would constitute unprofessional conduct for you to engage in a practice for which you have not been adequately trained. A is incorrect because it is unprofessional conduct to engage in a practice for which you have not been trained even if the client agrees to it. This is the same principle that applies to a client's "consent" to have sexual relations with a therapist. It is unethical for the therapist, regardless of what the client says. C is incorrect because trancework is one of a wide variety of therapeutic techniques that is within an MFT's scope of practice with the appropriate training. D is incorrect because this client is only requesting a service, not determining it. If the MFT had been adequately trained in this technique the MFT could choose to accept the client's request.

Congruence refers to consistency. This client is saying that the therapist is being inconsistent. A is incorrect because the client is not complaining about the fact that you have encouraged him to behave in a certain manner, only that your encouragement has been inconsistent. B is incorrect because the client is not complaining about your having been judgmental. D is incorrect because scope of practice is not addressed in the question.

Since empathic understanding is based on inference and use of one's imagination, feedback and verification from the client are needed in order to know if one's empathy is accurate. A is incorrect because, although empathy does use inference, the inferences need not be based on Psychodynamic Theory. B is incorrect because, although some therapists may need therapy in order to become sufficiently empathic, it is possible to be very empathic without any therapy at all. D is incorrect because accurate empathy may be experienced by the client as confrontive at times if the client is not ready to accept an aspect of his or her own thoughts and feelings.

Psychodynamic Theory generally holds that individuals have some degree of ambivalence about most things. When two members of a couple each have difficulty accepting and integrating their own ambivalence, they each only accept one side of their feelings, with the other often projected or at least assumed by the partner. A is incorrect because individuals are not usually confused about their roles if 1 they are able to perform them regularly and reliably, as this couple is described. B is   incorrect because oedipal conflicts usually involve issues of guilt, anxiety and personal ideals. This couple appears to be on opposite ends of a wide variety of issues. C is incorrect because isolation as a defense involves the separation of thought from feeling. The issue in this question is more a matter of separating two sides of ambivalence.

Missing sessions or coming late for sessions is generally considered to be an indicator of resistance to dealing with therapy or with difficult issues that are coming up in therapy. B is incorrect because, if the behavior is resistance, this would mean allowing the resistance to interfere with the therapeutic work. Besides, if this is resistance, then appointments would also be missed on the revised appointment schedule. C is incorrect because Mr. P might be hostile toward the therapist, but this would only be one of many possible reasons for the resistance. There is no specific evidence from the question that Mr. P is angry toward the therapist. His resistance might just as well be due to shame, anxiety or fear. A is a better answer. D is incorrect because Mr. P could be considered ready to terminate when his objectives have been met or when he has achieved the maximum level of therapeutic gain. There is no evidence of that in the question.

This is the most open ended question. A is incorrect because it could be answered with "yes" or "no". That doesn't stimulate much self- exploration. C is incorrect because "why" questions usually call on clients to make causal inferences that they are unprepared to make. It leads to intellectualization and abstract analysis, not self-exploration. D is incorrect because it could be answered with "yes" or "no". You might need this information in conducting a psychosocial assessment, especially in formulating a diagnosis, but the question posed in D would not be as effective in encouraging deeper self-exploration as the question in B would be.

People with obsessive compulsive personality disorder have difficulty making decisions because of their characteristic perfectionism and preoccupation with irrelevant detail. It's as if no decision will ever be perfect enough, especially when one is confused by an overwhelming barrage of detail. A is incorrect because this is a quality you would expect from someone with histrionic or dependent. personality disorder, not an obsessive compulsive personality disorder. B is incorrect because it describes a true obsession. You would expect to find that in an obsessive compulsive disorder, but not in an obsessive compulsive personality disorder. D is incorrect because grandiosity is associated with narcissistic personality disorder or manic episode, not with obsessive compulsive personality disorder.

Your obligation to make a mandated report is between you and the government authority that has issued the mandate. Agency policy does not override the law. You may not allow a supervisor to keep you from meeting your own legal obligations. C is incorrect because you would be required to make the report even if you were unable to gain your supervisor's agreement. D is incorrect because your reporting duty is clear. Consultation with attorneys should be saved for more complex legal matters.

A theme focus is the key to Psychodynamic Brief Therapy. A regressive flow of catharsis and exploration is more characteristic of open ended psychodynamic approaches. Therefore, A is incorrect. B is incorrect because the termination date and number of sessions should be specified, whether or not the objectives are achieved. If they are not, and the client still has a significant need for help, referral should be arranged to another resource. C is incorrect because brief therapy focuses on present issues and themes, not their initial causes. Initial causes may be pursued in open ended Psychodynamic Therapy.

This statement does not reveal that you know a Mr. Anderson, nor does it reveal anything about him. It also gives Mr. Anderson an opportunity to find out about his inheritance, if the caller is legitimate. A is incorrect because it reveals that you know Mr. Anderson. C is incorrect for the same reason that A is incorrect. D is incorrect because it implies that Mr. Anderson is a client and it may serve to deny Mr. Anderson the opportunity to find out about his inheritance.

This has been established in research. A is incorrect because there is little research evidence of the efficacy of individual therapy for solving marital problems. Besides, the term "primary cause" is a clue that the answer is incorrect. In family therapy it is generally assumed that no individual is a primary cause of a problem but that causation in family relationships is reciprocal. The problem is in the relationship, not in the person. C is incorrect because the efficacy of co-therapists over individual therapists has not been empirically established. D is incorrect because most behavioral therapy for marital problems is focused on operant (or voluntary) behaviors.

A is incorrect, in part, because there is no evidence that serial killers feel guilt when a victim survives their assault. C is incorrect because, even though survivors of childhood sexual abuse do often feel guilty for their own victimization, this is not referred to as survivor guilt. D is incorrect because there is no particular psychological concept that applies to this situation. 18'. The correct answer is D because hypomanic symptoms are not associated with hypochondriasis. Notice the word "except" in the question. In hypochondriasis a great deal of anxiety is involved and all three qualities described in A through C are affected. See the DSM manual for more information.

Loose associations refers to speech in which ideas shift from one subject to another completely unrelated subject, without the speaker's awareness of the shift. A is incorrect because magical thinking is more coherent. It refers to the false belief that one's thoughts, words or actions can cause outcomes that are unrealistic. C is incorrect because mood congruent psychotic features refers to delusions or hallucinations which correspond to a person's depression or elation. D is incorrect because ideas of reference are beliefs that events, objects or other people in the immediate environment have a special, unusual meaning for oneself. Such ideas are usually expressed more coherently than loose associations, even though they are unfounded.

Personality disorder is indicated by the long history and by the variety of dysfunctional coping mechanisms and dysfunctional thought that is of less than psychotic proportions. Schizotypal, histrionic or borderline personality disorder are especially suggested by the symptoms listed. A is incorrect because there is no evidence of true psychotic features in the question. C is incorrect because the distorted thinking described by the question is not characteristic of generalized anxiety disorder, and the question does not specifically refer to the experience of anxiety. D is incorrect because the described disorderis long standing since adolescence and adjustment disorders do not lead to such extreme distortions in thinking. Often when people with personality disorders experience stress,however, their more usual distorted thinking is exacerbated. However, when that happens an adjustment disorder should not be diagnosed.

When substance abusers have personality disorders, their substance abuse tends to follow the pattern described in the question, that is, beginning at a young age, using a wide variety of substances, and having comorbid psychiatric symptoms. A is incorrect because the notion of a single addictive personality pattern has been discounted through research. B is incorrect because, although temporal lobe epilepsy can mimic the symptoms of a personality disorder, there is no connection to the substance abuse pattern described in the question. C is incorrect because the substance abuse pattern described in the question is not particularly related to those who abuse alcohol.

Notice the word "except" in the question. Provision of structure is an important element in clinical work with personality disorder clients. Client Centered Therapy is extremely open ended and unstructured in its format. A is incorrect because personality disorder clients often have crises that need to be handled. Crisis management provides a clear task focus and structure. C is incorrect because personality disorder clients can often change specific maladaptive behaviors, even when the fundamental character structure is unchanged. D is incorrect because, even though confrontations by the therapist are likely to be problematic, confrontation by peers in a self-help situation is often recommended by experts in this field of practice.

You do not have enough information from the question to know whether or not this is a school phobia or a separation anxiety problem. If Micky is specifically afraid of being in school, even though he separates from his mother comfortably in other settings, then it would be a school phobia. If he is afraid of leaving his mother at school, at the local playground, at the babysitter's home, or anywhere else, then it would be a separation anxiety problem. D is incorrect because an eight year old child would normally have had at least two years of school experience and should have adapted to the school setting and to separation from parents.

Schizophrenia involves distractibility due to a fundamental deficit in selective inattention. People with other kinds of mental disorders might reduce their distractibility when treated with relaxation training or related psychophysiological stress management techniques. Distractibility in people with schizophrenia, however, does not substantially respond to such interventions. A is incorrect because avoidant personality disorder is not particularly associated with distractibility. C and D are incorrect because normal adults in either of these cultures are no more distractable than normal adults of other cultures.

B is incorrect because, even though family relationships might be addressed in this approach, they are not as central to the focus and purpose of the approach as is job functioning. C is incorrect because the approach emphasizes placement in jobs within the general workforce, not in sheltered workshops. D is incorrect because the focus is on placing a person in a job and then learning job skills through on the job training. As compared to developmentally disabled clients, psychiatric clients generally leam their job skills relatively quickly. The rehabilitation focus is on helping the clients learn to apply social skills to master problems that arise in the workplace culture and through interpersonal demands.

The AAMFT Code of Ethics allows for sexual relationships with former clients if at least two years have elapsed following termination. However, under these circumstances "the burden shifts to the therapist to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury to the former client or to the client's immediate family." A is incorrect because California state law also allows for sexual relationships with former clients if at least two years have elapsed following termination. B is incorrect because the therapist has a burden to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury to the former client or to the client's immediate family. The therapist would not have this burden in sexual relationships with other individuals. D is incorrect because there is no requirement that the therapist document that the relationship would not be harmful. The therapist's burden to demonstrate that there has been no exploitation or injury essentially applies in situations where the former client or an authorized representative of the former client claims that the relationship is harmful. The client would not have to prove that it was harmful, but the therapist would have to prove that it wasnlt harmful.

B is incorrect because a psychosomatic disorder is a true physical illness caused by or exacerbated by a psychological problem. This causal or exacerbating quality is not described in the question. C is incorrect because a factitious disorder involves the voluntary production of a symptom. The question does not raise this issue. D is incorrect because, even though the fatigue referred to in the question might be associated with psychomotor retardation, the other symptoms are not necessarily related.
Note the word "probably" in the question. Electroconvulsive therapy is used to treat severe depression, not the other conditions listed in the question.
Research has also shown that the risk of morbidity and mortality in the medically ill and elderly patient may actually be lower with ECT than with pharmacotherapy.

Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome is referred to as a "breathing-related sleep disorder" in DSM terminology. It involves multiple sleep interruptions due to blockage of the air passages. Reference to snoring is a clue. B is incorrect because this disorder, formerly known as a sleep-wake cycle disorder, involves the lack of a patterned time for falling asleep and waking from day to day. The symptoms described in the question suggest a lack of sleep, not this sleep schedule problem. C is incorrect because, even though the lapses in attention and concentration could be due to this disorder, the other features are much more likely to be associated with sleep apnea syndrome. D is incorrect because pica involves the repetitive eating of non-nutritive substances.

Notice the word "except" in the question. Steady state refers to a system's tendency to maintain behavior within a given range of variation. It is associated with homeostasis, a flexible balance achieved by maintaining behavior patterns within a range. However, these patterns may eventually shift toward either a healthy or unhealthy position as time goes on. A is incorrect because all system members play a role in maintaining the system's patterns. B is incorrect because a system's behavior patterns could not persist if they did not serve a function for the family as a whole, even though the effect might be problematic for one or more individuals in the family. C is incorrect because, even though steady state leads to a stable balance, this is not a rigid balance. Unlike "equilibrium," homeostasis does allow for some degree of change as circumstances change.

Note the words "most appropriate" in the question. A is incorrect because it is a double question. It asks about two issues at the same time. Such questions are confusing to clients. C is incorrect because it is a leading question. It influences the client to provide the answer that the interviewer favors. D is incorrect because it is too vague. If your purpose is to find out how well the client's crutches are working out you don't need to hear the client's comments about the aesthetics of the crutches' wood grain or how the crutches remind him of the ones used by his grandfather.

Note the word "best" in the question. In classical psychoanalysis where the therapist takes the position of a blank screen, something more akin to A, B or C might be in order. In the kind of situation described by the question, however, the best response is one that provides a simple, direct answer, then directs the focus back to the client as soon as possible.

Notice the word "except" in the question. B holds the woman responsible for her own abuse. Nobody does anything that causes another person to physically assault them. The abuser is responsible for acting abusively. A is incorrect. It helps to reduce guilt and self-blame. C is incorrect. It confirms that there is social support over such abuse and that society holds the perpetrator responsible. D is incorrect. It helps to universalize and, again, mitigates against self-blame. In other words, A, C and D are all things that should be said to an abused woman.

Injectable medications are longer lasting than oral medications and the client's stability would not depend on her remembering or choosing to regularly take medications. A is incorrect because electroconvulsive therapy (shock therapy) is a treatment for depression, not schizophrenia. B is incorrect because this would not be as reliably effective as the injectable medications. Also, since the client's noncompliance is due, in part, to an overestimation of her recovery, she might decide that she didn't need to attend the rehabilitation program any more than she needed to take the medications. D is incorrect because this approach would not be as reliably effective as injectable medications. The risk of rapid decompensation is too great in this case. However, if the client's decompensation was more gradual and suicide was not such a high risk, behavior modification might be sufficient to improve the client's medication compliance.

This is closest to the service requested by the client. B is incorrect because the client explicitly does not want to work on personality change. Also, her ability to cope with the problem she presents can be improved without making major personality change. C is incorrect because advice should be given sparingly and only when necessary. There is no indication from the question that this would be necessary. D is incorrect because it describes an approach that would be appropriate for long-term personality oriented therapy, not for the problem solving focus that the client is seeking and needing.

In this question, reference to dependency in the term "counterdependents" might be taken as a clue, since the therapist is the person most likely to be viewed as the caretaker and leader during this early phase of group development.

Notice the word "except" in the question. All effective group therapists need to assume a position of authoritative (not authoritarian) leadership. Rebellion against such constructive and functional leadership would generally be viewed as a transference, not a realistic reaction. A, B, and C are all realistic and problematic sources of frustration for group members.

Note the word "exclude" in the question. A is the only set, where all three elements are true; that is, all three should be excluded from such a therapy group. B is incorrect because neurotic clients do not need to be excluded. C is incorrect because physical disability has no bearing on a person's capacity to benefit from intensive, reconstructive group psychotherapy. D is incorrect because none of these diagnoses need to be excluded.

A is more associated with Minuchin's Structural Family Therapy. B is more associated with psychodynamic approaches to family therapy. Any approach to family therapy might actually deal with unresolved, covert sexual conflicts, but it is not a key feature of Conjoint Family Therapy. C is a better answer. D is more associated with Murray Bowen's Intergenerational Family Therapy.

Communication skills, like any other behaviors, are most rapidly and effectively learned through demonstration, practice, and feedback. B, C and D are incorrect because, even though these procedures can lead to positive growth, they have not been demonstrated to be as efficient and effective for learning new skills. B can lead to insight without behavior change. C can lead to positive growth but there is no focus on communication skills. Communication skills may or may not be among the clients' priorities for change as self-actualization develops. D may be effective if it is part of the demonstration used in the A sequence of demonstrate, practice and feedback. Otherwise the client may not identify with the therapist as a model, or the client may want to be like the model but, without an opportunity to practice and get feedback, may miss the mark.

This family is enmeshed because family members are unnecessarily emotionally reactive to one member's behavior, and without an adequate sense of boundaries and autonomy. A is incorrect because, in a disengaged family, members are minimally responsive to one another. B is incorrect because the question doesn't directly describe any dependency or codependency issues. D is incorrect because in order to depict inflexible structure the question would have had to describe the family over a period of time. Their structure would be inflexible if it did not change as needed when significant family events occurred such as the birth of an infant, the emancipation of a son or daughter, or the death of a family member.

Jay Haley, and other family therapists, note that a social system is composed of mutually influencing and interrelated members. All members influence one another. This includes the "identified patient" or symptom bearer. Cause- effect relationships are reciprocal. They do not begin with any one member and end with any one other member. Therefore, B and C are incorrect. The symptom bearer is not simply the victim or scapegoat of others. He or she is a participant in a mutual process. D is incorrect because family therapy focuses on the family group, not on society, even though it recognizes society as a family system's environment.

A and B are incorrect because family therapy of any kind is contraindicated for an older adolescent whose issue is psychological separation from the family. D is incorrect because residential treatment is best suited to more severe pathology where a structured and protective living environment is needed. Group therapy might be helpful with this kind of client, but it is not listed here. Individual therapy is the best option of the choices available.

Both the AAMFT Code of Ethics and state law prohibit you from paying compensation, monetary or otherwise, in exchange for a referral. However, state law specifically allows you to collaborate with a referral source, and to charge the client a fee for the collaboration as long as the client has been informed prior to the commencement of therapy about this fee practice, and nothing in the code of ethics prohibits a marriage and family therapist from doing so. B is incorrect because such a fee is explicitly allowed in state law and is not prohibited in the code of ethics. C is incorrect because both state law and the code of ethics prohibit you from compensating a referral source for a referral. Both monetary and non-monetary compensations are prohibited. D is incorrect because there is no reason to refuse the referral. The psychologist is acting unethically if he is terminating treatment for the purpose of entering into a sexual relationship with his former client, but this should not prohibit the client from receiving services hom another therapist, even if the referral came from the psychologist.

B is incorrect because, even though the therapist should be warm and empathic, she should be directive rather than exploratory. C is incorrect because the therapist need not be charismatic and should not be dramatic. D is incorrect because the therapist should be directive rather than exploratory, and active rather than passive.

In marriage and family therapy practice, all aspects of the process -- including assessment, treatment planning, interventions and termination -- should be conducted in a therapeutic manner. A client can gain a great deal of learning and insight through participating in a well developed assessment process. A is incorrect because survey research techniques are used for gathering descriptive data from large samples. There is no direct connection to comprehensive psychosocial assessment. C is incorrect because the assessment is the basis for formulating a treatment plan, not the outcome of a treatment plan. D is incorrect because the length of an assessment depends on the nature of the client and problem. Also, assessment is considered to be an ongoing process.

By definition, empathy means using one's imagination to put oneself into the psychological frame of reference of another person. Accurate empathy, then, involves sharing your imaginative insights with the client for confirmation and feedback about its accuracy. B is incorrect because, although fantasy may be the product of imagination, it usually has a defensive or need gratifying purpose. Defensiveness and need gratification are not a part of the empathic process. C is incorrect because empathy involves intellect, emotions, and images. Technical skill tends to focus on intellect and behavior. D is incorrect because it too refers to intellectual knowledge.

Note the words "tend" and "except" in the question. Latino cultures emphasize the organic wholeness of mind and body. B through D are incorrect because they all tend to be true in Latino cultures, although each individual and each family need to be assessed for their unique qualities within the culture.

Most Gestalt Therapy techniques are geared toward helping an individual become aware of a fuller range of their experiences. Often that means becoming more aware of ambivalences. The goal is greater self-acceptance and better integration of the whole (i.e. the gestalt). B is incorrect because it is more characteristic of the psychoanalytic view of psychopathology. C is incorrect because Gestalt Therapy does recognize psychopathology. D is incorrect because it is more characteristic of Behavior Modification.

A is incorrect because there is no evidence of intentionally manipulating staff to achieve a specific goal. B is incorrect because there is no evidence that Bill identifies with hospital staff. C is incorrect because psychic numbing refers to a reduction in general responsiveness to environmental stimuli. There is no evidence of that here.
Note the words "most likely" in the question. Splitting is characteristic of the borderline personality disorder. It is not particularly characteristic of the other diagnoses listed.

A is incorrect because, even though much of Humanistic Psychology borrows psychoanalytic concepts, the focus is on an individual's inherent capacity to grow and solve problems if they are provided with therapeutic conditions. This is different than Psychoanalytic Theory which relies more heavily on a therapist's insights into a client's psychodynamics, insights which are conveyed to the client through interpretation. C is incorrect because Gestalt Therapy gives little attention to the specific, observable reinforcement contingencies that shape behavior. D is incorrect because Rankian Psychology is a form of Psychoanalytic Theory.

State law regarding confidentiality and privileged communication does not allow for such a revelation except in specifically defined compelling circumstances. The law does not require you to report crimes sue . as burglary. If your client consents to your report of his crime, you may then reveal the information if you feel it would be in his best interest. In such circumstances it would be best, of course, to encourage the client to make his own report rather than doing it for him. B is incorrect because you may reveal confidential information, even information about a crime, with a client's consent. C is incorrect because California does not require reports of crimes such as burglary, even though it requires reports of crimes involving abuse of children, elders or dependent adults. D is incorrect because you may not report a his crime without his consent.

Depression often becomes worse in the winter, perhaps an 5 effect of reduced light during that season. While anxiety, guilt or cognitive functioning might fluctuate by season for some individuals because of special seasonal events that trigger these reactions, seasonal variation is not as commonly found as it is in the case of depression. Depression is the best answer. a

If one identical twin develops schizophrenia, the sibling will not necessarily develop schizophrenia. Therefore, their identical genetics do not cause the condition. However, the twin sibling has a greater chance of developing schizophrenia than does an unrelated person in the general population. That's because the genetic predisposition contributes to the condition. It creates a vulnerability to schizophrenia. C is incorrect because the term "exacerbate" refers to a condition becoming worse once it has been diagnosed. Therefore, a stressful event that happens during the course of someone's schizophrenia might exacerbate the schizophrenia, but genetic changes aren't likely to happen during midlife.
Some antidepressants are faster acting. Tricyclic antidepressants, however, require four to six weeks for sufficient blood levels to cause clinically observable change.

The marriage and family therapy profession's code of ethics does not require that clients be made aware of alternative services which could meet their needs. The important thing is that the client understands the treatment they are being offered and consents to that treatment. A and D are incorrect because these qualities are fundamental requirements of all ethical and legal approaches to the concept of informed consent. C is incorrect because the client must be informed of potential risks and benefits of treatments for which generally recognized standards do not yet exist. The AAMFT Code of Ethics does not require that a client be informed of potential risks and benefits of treatments for which generally recognized standards do exist. A cautious approach to this standard would take"generally recognized standards" to mean standards that are recognized by the general public as well as by professionals.

It is unethical to distort or misuse clinical findings. If you believe that neither the client nor her husband meet the criteria for a DSM diagnosis, as the question stipulates, then you should not put effort into trying to make a case for a DSM diagnosis, not for the purpose of obtaining payment nor for any other reason. A is 60'. The correct answer is MISSING. 61'. The correct answer is MISSING. 62'. The correct answer is MISSING. 63'. The correct answer is MISSING.

The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "marriage and family therapists encourage public participation in the design and delivery of professional services and in the regulation of practitioners." A is incorrect because such public participation should be encouraged, not discouraged. B is incorrect because the ethical standard specifically calls for participation by the public. It is not limited to encouraging participation by other members of the profession. D is incorrect because this issue is addressed in the professions code of ethics.

Note the word "best" in the question. What does the person mean by "a good job"? What does the person mean by "settle down for a change"? B is incorrect because a marriage and family therapist should begin where the client is and respect the client's right to self-determination. The client's request is what the client is motivated to do something about. C is incorrect because you don't know enough about the person yet to give realistic reassurance. D is incorrect because such a goal might be realistic, depending on what the person means by the request and depending on the kinds of therapeutic and socially supportive services that can be provided.

Note the words "most important" in the question. A positive response to short term therapy usually requires the ability to enter into a close relationship (with the therapist) in a short period of time, as well as the ability to tolerate the anxiety aroused by confrontation and rapid change. B is incorrect because neither conscience nor ego ideal, the two aspects of superego, are necessarily at issue in short term therapy. C is incorrect because "short term, interpretive psychotherapy" is psychodynamic, not behavioral, in nature. D is incorrect because the question asks about what short term, interpretive psychotherapy requires. The therapist's charisma might help, but it is not required for a positive response from the client.

Keep in mind that the question asks what you should do in the initial session. Also note that B says that you will be meeting with the couple "to review the way they are approaching their financial situation." A is incorrect because, even though there does appear to be a relationship problem here, that problem will need to be addressed in later sessions. Initially you should begin where the client is. C is incorrect because the client doesn't appear to be asking for technical advice about bookkeeping or investment strategies. He is asking for help with the way he and his Wife make decisions together. C is also incorrect because it uses the term "redirect," suggesting that the client would be offered a referral to a financial consultant instead of being able to see a marriage and family therapist. D is incorrect because the initial session is much too soon for this sort of assessment, especially in View of the client's request and presenting problem.

Avoidance of eye contact is an expression of cultural norms for many, but not all, Asian people. However, a person of any culture might also avert their eyes if they are shy, they have recently done something for which they feel shameful or guilty, or if they feel intimidated by the person they are with.

A is incorrect because the unequal power and authority inherent in the therapist/ client relationship means that a decision about this kind of relationship cannot truly be mutual on an equal, non-coercive basis. Also A through C are all incorrect because they all involve dual relationships of one kind or another. For example, a marriage and family therapist should not have their spouse for a client.

Practice approaches guided by Behavioral Theory are focused on the current sustaining conditions of a behavior, not the original cause. The other approaches listed are, however, concerned with understanding initial causes -- even going back to early childhood experiences -- as well as current sustaining conditions. Psychotherapy based on psychodynamic Ego Psychology theory gives less attention to initial causes of a problem than either classical Psychoanalysis or psychotherapy based on Self Psychology. However, Ego Psychology based approaches are more likely to address these issues than the approaches based on Behavioral Theory.

You have an ethical obligation to use only methods that are within your scope of competence and a legal obligation to use only methods that are within your scope of practice. If the client needs help in achieving other goals that cannot be achieved using methods within your scope of practice and competence, the client should be referred out for such help. A is incorrect because the most important goals might not be the one's that can be achieved in the shortest amount of time. B is incorrect because the client may need to, and want to, pay out of pocket to work on goals that are not within the parameter of his or her insurance coverage. D is incorrect because the theoretical approach should be selected according to the client's individualized assessment findings. Cognitive behavioral therapy has demonstrated efficacy in treating certain problems with certain kinds of clients. It is not necessarily the best approach to use in any situation.

Anxiety can motivate change if it is not overwhelming and debilitating. The stem of the question does not say that the client's anxiety is overwhelming. A is incorrect because it uses the term "always." Although you should reduce anxiety through support and reassurance if the anxiety is interfering with therapy, you should not reduce it in this manner if it is contributing to therapy. C is incorrect because the stem of the question does not say that the anxiety is overwhelming. D is incorrect because most people feel anxious during early therapy sessions, regardless of their character structure. Clients are anxious because they are entering a relationship with a stranger, revealing sensitive thoughts and feelings, and unsure about their prospects for resolving the problem that brought them to therapy.

The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists continue therapeutic relationships only so long as it is reasonably clear that clients are benefitting from the relationship." A is incorrect because, even though a client has the right to terminate at any time, you are not obliged to recommend termination whenever a client requests termination. A client who still needs service may request termination due to ambivalence or resistance to change. In such instances you should help the client understand the underlying motivation and inform the client of the possible consequences of termination. B is incorrect because client resistance is common and can be worked through. D is incorrect because countertransferences are common and can also be resolved.

There is no reason to believe that the client is unable to resolve the problem directly with her current hospital social worker. Getting involved could lead to triangulation and confusion. B is incorrect because of the reason just stated. C is incorrect because it simply calls on the client to accept an inadequate discharge plan instead of encouraging the client to work toward a more satisfactory plan. D is incorrect because it is tangential to the presenting problem.

Obsessions and compulsions are, by definition, ego dystonic. A is incorrect because people with personality disorders don't experience their character traits as problematic or ego alien. C is incorrect because, even though people with substance use disorders will, from time to time, be troubled by their addiction and want to quit, they are more characteristically in denial. They View their compulsive pattern of substance use as something that they want for themselves. D is incorrect because factitious disorder is voluntarily initiated. People with factitious disorder see the symptoms as something they want to be doing.

The symptoms suggest clinically significant depression. Suicide risk is associated with depression and risks should be addressed first in an assessment. A through Care incorrect because, even though these things should be done, they should not be "your first activity."

Your client's condition is probably a brief psychosis. It is probably not schizophrenia (which typically first occurs during the second and third decades of life) or a psychotic disorder due to a general medical condition (in which the psychotic features do not usually occur suddenly). When brief psychoses go into remission the person returns to their previous level of functioning.

A client first coming to you in crisis will derive a sense of realistic reassurance from this kind of structure. C is incorrect because "authoritarian" involves an unquestioning obedience to authority, rather than individual freedom of judgment and action. "Authoritative," on the other hand, refers to competent authority based on qualifications, knowledge, skill and expertise. D is incorrect because you can't begin where the client is if you don't focus on the crisis. Acknowledge the client's strengths as they become apparent, but not as a way of avoiding or minimizing the crisis. A is incorrect because, especially with a new client, you don't know if the problem will be resolved. You only know that it can be resolved.

The Elder and Dependent Adult Abuse Reporting Act requires a report if you have a reasonable suspicion that physical abuse, isolation, abduction, fiduciary abuse, or neglect have occurred. The law permits but does not require a report regarding mental suffering. The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists do not disclose client confidences except by written authorization or waiver, or where, mandated or permitted by law." Therefore the code of ethics also permits but does not require a report in this situation. A is incorrect because a report of mental suffering is optional, not mandated, under the law. C is incorrect because the code of ethics allows you to disclose client information where permitted by law. D is incorrect because the code of ethics permits you to disclose client information by making the report, but it doesn't require you to do so.

Note the word "least" in the question. A is incorrect because a person's developmental stage is always relevant to assessing ego functioning. For example, you wouldn't expect to find the same level of judgment, abstract thinking, or calculation ability in a three year old as you would in a forty year old. C is incorrect because reality testing is an ego function, therefore it is relevant to assessing ego functioning. D is incorrect because culture shapes the way in which we express our ego functions. For example, when assessing the ego function of object relations we need to remember that some cultures support independence and others support mutual dependence. When assessing the ego function of judgment we need to remember that some cultures support risk taking, others support minimizing risks. In general, you would expect to find strong similarities between two forty year old men and women of a particular culture. You would expect to find strong dissimilarities between a five year old and forty year old. You would expect to find strong dissimilarities between a sub- Saharan farmer and a New York City stockbroker.

Both federal and state law, and ethical standards, allow information to be shared among staff of a facility or program, even without the client's permission. However, the profession's code of ethics and federal HIPAA regulations require that the client be informed of such practices in writing. B is incorrect because the law and ethical standards do allow you to discuss your client with a fellow staff member at a program. C is incorrect because you do not have a duty to confirm the confidentiality commitment of your colleagues. D is incorrect because the colleague does not need to obtain such a written release from the client. This would be required if you were in a private practice and the requesting party was not an associate of your private practice, but it is not required in the situation described by this question.

You may terminate a client with an overdue balance, and there is no prohibition against doing so, as long as the termination is done in a way that does not constitute client abandonment. The most ethical approach to this issue is one in which you have previously informed the client that this would be the consequence of an overdue balance, you've determined that the client is not at imminent risk, and the consequences of failure to make payment have been discussed with the client. B is incorrect because the payment is already overdue. The client has already failed to keep a previous promise regarding payment for services. C is incorrect because the client may not need another therapist, or may not need one to be readily available. This would depend on the client's clinical condition. D is incorrect because termination is ethically . permissible under the conditions described above.

Since the client's primary purpose is to reduce anxiety and agitation, any therapeutic interventions to accomplish this goal while the client is still using amphetamines would be ineffective and wasteful. You should not, however, abandon the client. If termination became necessary you should make the client aware of the appropriate resources for assistance in overcoming an amphetamine addiction. B is incorrect because it compounds the client's chemical dependency by adding another drug without resolving the dependency problem. C is incorrect because the client's thinking will be distorted as long as he is using amphetamines. Insight will be impaired by denial and confusion arising from the effects of the amphetamines. D is incorrect because you don't know that this client has a need for such intensive medical support during detoxification and there is no specific evidence that the conditions for a medically necessary hospitalization are met.

Note the word "except" in the question. The law and the Code of Ethics require you to take any one of the three actions described in A, B and C. It does not require you to involve the client in what may become a tense relationship between yourself and the court. Also, keep in mind that this client has not consented to reveal the information. It would be unethical for you to deal with your obligation to the court by asking a person whom you know to be an unwilling participant to carry out your responsibility.

This is a question about Erikson's developmental framework. These are qualities that are established in personality during the stage of initiative vs. guilt, which corresponds to Freud's Oedipal stage, and which occurs between the ages of about four through six.

Note the word "least" in the question. In A, B and D psychotic symptoms are prominent and defining features. Schizotypal personality disorders, however, may not involve the experience of psychotic symptoms and these symptoms are not among the defining features of the disorder.

Research evidence shows that panic attacks due to panic disorder can be resolved in as little as three or four months when the appropriate treatment method is used. After 10 months of no progress you should either change your treatment method or, if you are using a method that should be effective, refer the client to another therapist. This would be consistent with the AAMFT ethical standard which states "Marriage and family therapists continue therapeutic relationships only so long as it is reasonably clear that clients are benefitting from the relationship." A is incorrect because there is usually no good reason to provide more of something that hasn't been effective. B is incorrect because a change of treatment methodology might be sufficient to improve effectiveness. This approach could take advantage of any therapeutic alliance that has been established. C is incorrect because there is no evidence that intensive process oriented group psychotherapy is an effective means of eliminating panic attacks due to panic disorder. C is also incorrect because it doesn't address the need for you to change your approach.

An understanding of the client's developmental past is one way of better understanding the client's present personality. Also, your understanding of a client's past can help you communicate with clients when they speak about memories of the past and their current thoughts and feelings about those memories. B would be correct if all marriage and family therapists used a behavioral approach. However, since a rich variety of theories are used, and since exam questions are usually not based on a particular theory unless specified, you should pay attention to this client's early developmental experiences. They might be very important to the client and may help the client understand current motivations and conflicts. This is especially relevant in a case like this Where the client sees his problem as something more than simple behavior patterns. C is incorrect because, in marriage and family therapy practice, attention is given to early experiences primarily as a way of understanding the present. D is incorrect because diagnosis of mental disorder is based on current symptom patterns, not on etiology or initial causative experiences.

It is rarely necessary for students to know the identity of a client when the client's case material is being presented for teaching purposes. A is incorrect because you wouldnlt need such a confidentiality commitment if you took sufficient steps to protect the client's identity. Even after taking such steps, it is a good idea to ask students to treat the information confidentially just in case they or others recognize a subtle identifying feature that you have overlooked, but the fundamental protection is not the students' confidentiality commitment...it is the steps you take to protect the clients identity. B is incorrect because, even though this is an acceptable approach, the better approach is to avoid using identifying information in the first place, especially because you have no way of assuring that students would actually protect the confidentiality of your client if identifying information was presented to them. C is incorrect because you would have to reveal something about your client's identity in the process of checking to see if any of the students knew the client.

A refers to a behavioral intervention that is used to reduce anxiety in the presence of anxiety arousing stimuli. Most marriage and family therapists would consider it reductionistic (an oversimplification) to simply view this client's problems as anxiety responses to particular stimuli. They involve his sense of identity, self-image, object relations, belief systems, and other issues that are imbued with meaning. B is incorrect because it also refers to another behavioral intervention that is used to reduce anxiety in the presence of anxiety arousing stimuli. D is incorrect because approach would not be change oriented and a short term approach would probably not be sufficient since he presents a complex problem with many facets.

According to Erik Erikson, the person of integrity has a profound acceptance of self and others, including one's parents. They look beyond what their parents did and did not do for them and, instead, they look at the ways in which their parents were people "like me." Integrity involves a sense that we each do as well as we possibly can with the resources, life circumstances and historical conditions available to us. B is incorrect because the client needs to develop a better understanding of his perceptions and see what he can learn from them. The approach presented in B would only lead the client to suppress or repress his perceptions and feelings. C is incorrect because, even though it is possible, A is more likely. D is incorrect because it assumes the client's negative view and reinforces it. This approach has been associated with "false memory syndrome." A better approach would be to help the client uncover more specific memories of his experiences with his parents, both positive and negative, not only their mistreatment of him.

Legal reporting mandates apply to individual practitioners, not usually to agencies. All other response options are incorrect because they are the prerogative of supervisors and managers. The professional marriage and family therapist should, however, have input into developing policies, procedures and assignments.

Consider, for example, Jews. Not all Jewish people observe the same religion. Some observe no religion at all. Some are Buddhists. Even if a Jewish person were-to accept Christianity he or she would still be recognized as a Jewish Christian. Although Jewish people had a common nationality in Biblical times, they were identified as a people with a common history even before entering their ancient nation. Although members of an ethnic group often have a common political interest, they will often share this political interest with others, and there is often a variety of political interests among members of an ethnic group, especially members of various socioeconomic classes.

In family therapy these "sequences of behavior among people" are the family's communications, or family dynamics. The experienced family therapist focuses on changing the family system. A is incorrect because, even when a key individual is the focus of change as in Bowen's approach to family therapy, the individual's change is sought because of its effect on the sequences of behavior between that individual and others in the family. C is incorrect because not all families have two parents, and not all family problems are directly related to the parental coalition. D is incorrect because family therapy focuses on changing the family system, not the individual whom the family has labeled as "the problem."

Integration means action by the family system to bring about harmonious interaction of component members in service of the family's goals. People in any kind of group will work toward harmonious interaction to the extent that they become aware of their common goals and mutual needs. A is incorrect because, even though it refers to a desirable quality in family life, the focus on differences is not as directly related to integration as a focus on commonalities. B is incorrect because all systems have roles and norms, whether or not they are well integrated. D is incorrect because all stable systems, including well integrated systems, have dominance hierarchies. In a well integrated family system the dominance hierarchy is one that will likely feel acceptable and even desirable to the family members.

Positive change in group members is promoted in psychotherapy groups and other groups that favor experimentation and flexibility. A is incorrect because positive change is fostered in groups that are group centered with an open system of communication, rather than in groups that are leader centered. B is incorrect because an open airing of conflict is needed for a group to resolve conflicts, develop mutually acceptable resolutions, and develop cohesiveness. Open airing of conflict would also give your client opportunities to learn and practice assertion skills. D is incorrect because the presence or absence of co-therapists has little bearing on the objectives that may be achieved through group therapy.

This finding has been established in empirical research on the misdiagnosis of clients with "major depression with psychotic features." The misdiagnosis also occurs with clients of other ethnicities, but at a somewhat higher rate among African American clients.

This principle is stated in the AAMFT Code of Ethics. A is incorrect because ethical practice requires that informed consent be provided from either the client or a legally authorized person. B is incorrect because a supervisor has no authority to speak on behalf of a client. D is incorrect because a child's parents may not be the ones legally authorized to give consent. For example, in some cases of abuse, neglect or abandonment the court may assume authority to authorize a child's services "in loco parentis." C is a better answer than D because it is more inclusive.

Note the words "Your client is" (a definitive statement) in the question. Delusions and hallucinations are psychotic symptoms. A is incorrect because this client's psychotic symptoms may be due to a serious long term mental disorder such as schizophrenia, but they might also be having these symptoms because of intoxication, abuse, a brief psychosis, or a medical condition. The latter conditions lead to symptom remission with time and/or treatment. B is incorrect because, although the client may be abusing drugs, it is too conclusive a statement to say that the client is abusing drugs. You don't have enough information to know that. D is incorrect because you have enough information to know that the individual is acutely psychotic but much more information would be needed in order to know that the psychosis was due to schizophrenia.

We need to be dependent about some issues in our lives, and independent about others. When we need to be dependent, we should be able to place that dependency in people who are trustworthy and capable, not just anybody. A and B are incorrect because they are too one sided. C is incorrect because a person with healthy object relations would be open to accepting dependency from others when appropriate, but would not invite it whenever possible.

The primary task of group psychotherapy is to accomplish personal change and growth through honest self-exploration. Trying to project any particular image of oneself to other members, and trying to win others.' approval will not accomplish this. A is incorrect because this client may be engaging in these behaviors primarily in relation to the other group members, not because of his relationship with the therapist. B is incorrect because these behaviors might be present only in this kind of group situation. Characterological manipulation would be persistent and pervasive, but there is no indication that this is the case for this client. D is incorrect because C is correct, and D presents an opposite statement.

A is incorrect because it would be a violation of confidentiality. The destructive potential of the client's behavior is not sufficient to warrant a Tarrasoff warning. B is incorrect for the same reason that A is incorrect and because the client will likely hold you responsible for the outcome of having followed your advice. D is also incorrect because the client will likely hold you responsible for the outcome of having followed your advice. C is correct because the client needs to know that her behavior is manipulative and deceptive, and learn about herself to the extent that this issue has a bearing on the goals and purpose of your therapeutic contract.

A is incorrect because behavior modification does not use techniques for this kind of self-exploration. B and C are incorrect because, even though therapists using these approaches might occasionally use the empty chair technique, the technique was developed by and is primarily associated with Gestalt Therapy. D therefore, is the best choice.

Empathic listening involves using one's imagination to experience the client's thoughts and feelings as if they were one's own. A, B and D incorrect because they do not rely as much on the clinician's personal resources. A, B, and D could conceivably be done by a well-programmed computer, but a person's imagination and sensitive listening are required for truly empathic listening.

This approach is indicated by the fact that you have two weeks to accomplish the requested objective and by the fact that the client is not interested in fundamental personality change. A and B are incorrect because these treatment strategies are geared to long term personality change and would not likely achieve any significant change within two weeks. C is incorrect because it probably wouldn't be helpful.

Although a family therapist strives to focus on the family as a whole and be impartial to each of its members, identifications, biases and countertransferences are inevitable from time to time. In order to maintain credibility and a sense of genuineness in the therapeutic relationship, this should be shared with the clients. This is effective modeling and provides "grist for the mill" when examining behavior sequences with the family. A is incorrect because the therapist's human qualities inevitably lead to identification, bias and countertransferences at times, especially in contentious situations such as this one. C is incorrect because nonverbal cues will inevitably reveal the experience of taking sides. By failing to acknowledge what is already revealed anyway, the therapist loses credibility and models dysfunctional communication. D is incorrect because the family therapist needs to focus on the family system, and avoid the temptation to rescue an individual.

A primitive defense mechanism is one that leads to the greatest distortion of reality, is available at a very young age, and is relatively dysfunctional, even when it is effective in reducing immediate anxiety. Denial fails to acknowledge reality, and it is available even in infancy as when a baby closes his eyes or turns his head away from something he doesn't want to acknowledge. A is incorrect because sublimation is one of the most advanced defense mechanisms. By definition it effectively leads to adaptation. C and D are incorrect because these defenses are not available at a young age. They require verbal and intellectual skills that are not available in infancy. They are also somewhat more accessible to influence through rational discussion than is denial.

Acceptance by the therapist promotes the client's acceptance of self. This leads to a sense of integrity or wholeness, which makes it possible for the client to know what he or she most needs. A is incorrect because acceptance can include acknowledging one's negative aspects or limitations. This does not always directly contribute to self-esteem. C is incorrect because the therapist's influence is not the major focus of change in Client Centered Therapy, the approach most likely serving as a frame of reference for this question. D is incorrect because not all clients are seeking to enhance their sense of altruism. This treatment approach takes no moralistic stand on whether or not a client should become more altruistic, only that the client become more of whatever is the true self.

Prevalence of mental disorders is about the same when African Americans are compared to Americans of European descent. Socioeconomic status has a greater association with prevalence than does ethnicity.

Good prognostic signs include sudden onset, onset triggered by a stressor, recent onset, and high premorbid functioning. Poor prognostic signs include insidious onset, onset in the absence of a stressor, and chronic history. If the symptoms are ego syntonic motivation to change will be minimal or absent. If the symptoms are a manifestation of a personality disorder (the conditions described in answer C) the prognosis will also be poor. Note that, among other things, A is the pattern found in an adjustment disorder, B is the pattern found in schizophrenia, C is the pattern found in personality disorder, and D is also commonly found in personality disorder and chemical dependency. *

No compensation, whether monetary or otherwise, may be paid for the referral of professional clients. A and B are incorrect because, even though this kind of bartering agreement would be unprofessional conduct in a therapist/ client relationship, bartering is not prohibited as an aspect of a rental agreement. The therapist would have to be careful to assure that neither the rental agreement nor the bartering influences any professional collegial relationship with the psychologist. C is incorrect because there is no prohibition against basing rental payments on a proportion of gross income.

A is incorrect. A would be correct if the mood symptoms were more prominent and occurred first. C is incorrect. C would be correct if the psychotic symptoms were characteristic of schizophrenia, and if the psychotic symptoms were more prominent and occurred first. D is incorrect because psychotic symptoms are not a defining feature of the schizotypal personality disorder.

Although repressed or suppressed distress might become manifest in either of these ways, cultural norms in some Asian cultures favor expression through somatization or dissociation. A is incorrect because anxiety is a direct expression of emotional distress, not an alternative means of expression. It is also incorrect because anger could imply dissatisfaction with the status quo, rather than mask one's dissatisfaction. B is incorrect because acting out would also directly reveal one's dissatisfaction, and it is not particularly associated with norms of Asian cultures. D is incorrect because intellectualization or rationalization are defense mechanisms which tend to be favored by people of higher intelligence or education across cultures. They are not particularly associated with norms of Asian cultures. Also, people of average intelligence or lower educational attainment in Asian cultures would be less likely to use these defenses, as would be true for similar individuals in other cultures.

Note the word "except" in the question. You are permitted to advertise your services, including your availability for referrals, as long as the advertising is neither false nor misleading. A, C and D are all specifically prohibited as unprofessional conduct under California state law. 115'. The correct answer is MISSING. disturbed social relatedness are not characteristic of mentally retarded children. C is incorrect because, even though the lack of social relatedness may be found in autism, normal speech would not be expected and other characteristic symptoms of autism are not described here.  D is incorrect because, even though a simple adjustment problem would involve sadness or anxiety after suffering such a loss and displacement, after five months most children probably would have made a better social adjustment than the one described here.

Separation anxiety usually first appears during the latter months of a child's first year and is developmentally characteristic of young toddlers. A is incorrect because such young infants do not experience separation anxiety. C and D are incorrect because separation anxiety at these ages would indicate a problem, not a developmentally appropriate experience.

B is incorrect because, although some delusions are paranoid delusions, not all paranoia is delusional. This client's description says nothing about a firmly held, false paranoid belief that almost nobody else believes. These are the qualities that distinguish paranoid delusions from the more common paranoid personality trait. C is incorrect because hallucinations are sensory experiences without a corresponding external stimulus. Paranoia, on the other hand, is usually a matter of what a person thinks or believes, not what they experience in a sensory way. D is incorrect I because, even though paranoia usually causes stress, it is not necessarily caused by stress. For example, it may be caused by long standing personality patterns, substance use, or organic causes, even in the absence of stress. A is correct because problematic, persistent and pervasive personality tendencies are called personality traits.

It is unethical and unprofessional conduct to provide anything of material value in exchange for receiving a referral. You are free to refer a client to the colleague at some time in the future, but A is incorrect because that referral may not be "in exchange" for the referral that you received. Referrals should be based solely on what is in the best interest of the client.

Note the word "except" in the question. Unlike rejected children who have difficulty entering into interpersonal relationships, overindulged children enter readily into relationships. However, when they do their behavior tends to be exploitive, antisocial and aggressive.

Church or synagogue attendance has been found to mitigate against depression upon death of a spouse. Also, men are more prone than women to experience depression upon death of a spouse. It has been hypothesized that this effect is due to either women's greater access to social supports or men's socialized reluctance to use their social supports effectively due to suppressed emotion and a reluctance to speak openly of problems and vulnerabilities.

This implies acceptance of the exam outcome, whatever it might be. B and D are incorrect because they anticipate a good result on the exam, but there is no way of knowing what the result will be. C is incorrect because it minimizes the importance of the examination, even though the exam might be important to the client. Also, C would deprive the client of a sense of pride if he or she were to do well on the exam.

This is both a legal and ethical issue. Clients have a legal right to access the information in their clinical records. B is incorrect because the Code of Ethics allows you to limit access for the reasons listed in answer A. C is incorrect because many clients would be able to know their diagnosis without serious harm. D is incorrect because the therapist's fantasies shouldn't be in a clinical record. However, even if they were, they would only be off limits if they met the kind of circumstances specified in answer A.

Empathic listening will allow the traumatized spouse to work through the experience at her own pace and without the pressure of external expectations. A and B are often associated with increased stress for the traumatized spouse. C is not effective because it gives a false reassurance.

Low self-esteem and a sense of worthlessness are associated with depression. Depression is the core feature of a dysthymic disorder and these two symptoms are among the defining criteria of this disorder. Although low self- esteem and a sense of worthlessness might also be associated with any of the other disorders listed, especially schizophrenia, they are associated features, not core or defining features, of these other diagnoses. B, therefore, is the best answer.

Vegetative signs of depression are the physical, as opposed to psychological, signs. All symptoms listed in C are physical. The other response options contain psychological signs such as recurrent thoughts about death or feelings of worthlessness.

The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Information may be shared only to the extent necessary to achieve the purposes of the consultation." A is incorrect because the consultant might request information out of curiosity that is not relevant to achieving the purposes of the consultation. It is your responsibility to protect the client's confidentiality, and you may not simply rely on the consultant's discretion in this matter. B is incorrect because the client might be willing for you to release more information than is necessary. You would still have an ethical responsibility to present information only as necessary to achieve the consultation purpose. C is incorrect because you may reveal such private information if the client has given consent and if it is relevant to achieving the purpose of the consultation.
Intimacy vs. isolation is the stage of young adulthood. It follows identity vs. identity diffusion which is the primary conflict of adolescence.

By definition, a mental disorder is a clinically significant syndrome involving distress or impaired social functioning. These qualities must be present before assigning any DSM diagnosis to a client, including the NOS diagnoses. A and B are incorrect because these response options refer to symptoms of certain NOS diagnoses, but they do not apply to all NOS diagnoses. C is incorrect because many mental disorders, and therefore many NOS diagnoses, have a physical or cognitive etiology, not psychodynamic.

The AAMFT Code of Ethics states that "Marriage and family therapists make efforts to prevent the distortion or misuse of their clinical and research findings." The actions described in answer B fulfill this ethical standard. A is incorrect because it is insufficient to disclaim ownership of the misinterpretation. The ethical standard calls on you "to prevent the distortion or misuse" of your information. C is incorrect because this ethical responsibility is established in the code of ethics. The responsibility to correct the misinformation does not depend on whether or not you have caused or contributed to it. D is incorrect because there is a way in which just about anything is true. Presumably your original report presented what you have established to be true. Answer D suggests an effort to take advantage of your colleagues error to promote your own self interest.

This requirement is set forth in Business and Professions Code Sec. 4982 regarding unprofessional conduct. A is incorrect because substance use is not prohibited per se. It is prohibited if the substance is used to the extent, or in a manner, as to be dangerous or injurious to the MFT or to any other person, or if it impairs the ability of the MFT to safely conduct the practice of marriage and family therapy. B is incorrect because the use of illegal substances is prohibited by other laws, but the Business and Professions Code only addresses this issue to the extent that it is relevant to the MFT's professional practice, as just described. C is incorrect because the law does not reference diagnostic criteria. A person might meet the criteria for alcohol abuse, for example, in a way that does not create a significant danger to clients or to the public.

Under California law it is unprofessional conduct to MISSING 132'. The correct answer is MISSING. 133'. The correct answer is MISSING. 134'. The correct answer is MISSING. 135'. The correct answer is MISSING. 136'. The correct answer is MISSING. 137'. The correct answer is MISSING. 138'. The correct answer is MISSING. incorrect because the Tarasoff obligation applies whether or not the client's behavior would constitute a felony. Therefore A is true but D is a better answer because it is more inclusive and reflects the actual legal obligation as stated in the judicial decision. B is incorrect because the Tarasoff decision does not apply to any serious harm. It only applies to a serious danger of violence. C is incorrect because the decision applies to serious violence rather than just any serious harm, and because the therapist has no obligation to inform the intended victim when the client is deemed to no longer pose a danger.

Anticipatory guidance is widely recognized as an effective means of reducing stress reactions to predictable stressors. A is incorrect because you cannot effectively and significantly build a person's self-esteem in three days. C is incorrect because this would be false assurance. You don't really know if the person will be able to handle the stress effectively. D is incorrect because, even though some psychological conditions might warrant postponement of surgery, simple anxiety is not sufficient cause. Most everyone is anxious in anticipation of surgery.

Note the word "except" in the question. Level of education doesn't help a person manage stress. B is incorrect because our sense of adequacy and worthiness lead to confidence and the ability to cope with stress. C is incorrect because the very purpose of ego defenses is to manage anxiety, including the anxiety that results from stress.
