D is incorrect because understanding the nature of a stressful situation gives a person a sense of control, a "cognitive grasp" as it is referred to in the crisis intervention literature.

The law states that "When any person, as a result of mental disorder, is a danger to others, or to himself or herself, or gravely disabled, a peace officer, member of the attending staff, as defined by regulation, of an evaluation facility designated by the county, designated members of a mobile crisis team provided by Section 5651.7, or other professional person designated by the county may, upon probable cause, take, or cause to be taken, the person into custody and place him or her in a facility designated by the county and approved by the State Department of Mental Health as a facility for 72-hour treatment and evaluation." A is incorrect because the law does not authorize any marriage and family therapist to involuntarily hold a person. The MFT must be specially designated, for example by virtue of being on the staff of a mobile crisis team. C is incorrect because any peace officer may involuntarily hold an individual under this law if the peace officer believes the person to be a danger due to a mental disorder. The assumption regarding the mental disorder does not need to be confirmed by a mental health professional. D is incorrect because only certain designated mental health professionals may hold a person involuntarily, regardless of the opinion of a peace officer.

Note the word "except" in the question. While you should accept the client's expressions of anger and even retribution if that's what the client is thinking and feeling, you should not encourage such expression. B is incorrect. You should be supportive rather than confrontive. C is incorrect. You should allow the client to repeatedly talk about the trauma. This can be used as the basis for developing a sense of understanding and restoring a sense of control. D is incorrect. This intervention can serve to protect the client's health and help her maintain the stamina needed for effective therapeutic engagement.
Note the word "especially" in the question. Fear and anxiety are exceptionally subject to conditioning and to being transferred (generalized) to previously neutral stimuli.

Resistance and flight into health often occur in the middle phase of therapy. It is a way of avoiding the increasingly difficult issues that arise after early defenses are worked through. A is incorrect because the request to terminate came suddenly and without a substantial resolution of the clients' major problem. C is incorrect because no specific evidence of this is provided in the vignette. D is incorrect because countertransference refers to the therapist's thought, feelings and/or behavior, not the client's.

Enmeshment and disengagement are problems of resonance. In enmeshment family members are much too responsive to one another's thoughts, feelings and actions. They resonate or react to the slightest cue, thereby interfering with the autonomy of individual family members. In disengagement there is very little resonance to one another, even when important issues are raised by a family member. A is incorrect because family systems are not designed. They arise and grow through natural development, not intentional planning. B is incorrect because a family's resonance relates to any issue in family life, not just authority issues. D is incorrect because enmeshment and disengagement are more directly related to family process or dynamics rather than structure.

Note the word "except" in the question. Free floating anxiety is not directly related to depression, self-doubt or vulnerability to exploitation by others. In any case, it is not as directly related as are the other three qualities listed: self- assertion skills, self-esteem and self-acceptance.

The client's threat should be taken seriously, especially because she is depressed, has a specific plan, has the means to carry it out, and expresses an immediate intention to act within the next few days. B is incorrect because it does not address the risk. C is incorrect because it does not address the risk sufficiently. Under these circumstances even three or four outpatient sessions per week might not provide sufficient monitoring. D is incorrect because an abrupt termination would constitute client abandonment and because you should be able to manage a suicide risk, in collaboration with others such as the psychiatrist.

There is no need to renegotiate the treatment plan if primary goals and objectives have been achieved. If the client seeks to renegotiate at this point, it is probably a regression and will serve as an opportunity to learn about how the client handles loss. Termination is a loss and, if sufficient time is allotted to work it through, clients can learn skills in coping with loss during the termination process (A). Also, client regression often occurs at termination as a way of trying to reverse the decision and maintain the relationship (B). Finally, if a client takes the termination as a rejection, the client is apt to find ways to reject the therapist in return, perhaps by devaluing the therapist and expressing hostility (C). A

A is incorrect because it is not unusual for survivors to hear the voice or sense the presence of the deceased. B is incorrect because depression is perhaps the most characteristic symptom of bereavement. D is incorrect because agitation often expresses the survivor's anxiety and attempts to create distractions from his or her depressing thoughts. C may occur in bereavement, but it is not as characteristic as are the other symptoms listed. Impaired immediate recall is a sign of organic mental disorder.

Note the words "least helpful" in the question. A Interpretive psychotherapy is usually to be avoided in work with clients who have schizophrenia. The abstract nature of interpretive inferences are confusing to the thought disordered client. Confronting defenses may also be unnecessarily threatening, especially to a client who is paranoid. Case management is needed to provide social support and assistance in obtaining resources and an alternative living arrangement (A). Medications may be needed to restore impulse control and control the symptoms that likely led to the late night outbursts (B). Psychosocial rehabilitation may also be needed to learn better ways of coping with stresses that may have led to the outbursts (D). Also, this client may need help in an apartment search and in negotiating relationships with a new landlord and neighbors.

The stage of intimacy vs. isolation immediately follows the stage of identity vs. identity diffusion or role diffusion. Erikson explains that in order to feel the security needed to risk one's identity by fusing it with that of another person, one must first feel secure in one's own identity. B is incorrect because the developmental issue of generativity vs. stagnation follows intimacy vs. isolation. Generativity becomes possible once we have learned to enter into the intimate relationships that make it possible to generate families, projects and careers. C is incorrect because the question is based on an Eriksonian conceptual framework. Erikson does not focus on such Freudian psychosexual issues as the Oedipal conflict. D is incorrect because Erikson's theory is not a theory of psychotherapy. He does not prescribe the method for achieving growth and development. Instead, he focuses on describing the sequence of issues that must be addressed as a person grows and develops.

Frequency refers to how often the behavior occurs. Magnitude refers to the strength or intensity of the behavior. Duration refers to how long the behavior lasts when it does occur. B is incorrect because it ignores duration. Magnitude and intensity mean essentially the same thing. C is incorrect because motivation, capacity and situation opportunities are three important aspects of all clinical assessments, but they are not particularly relevant to establishing a behavioral baseline. These concepts are too abstract to serve as a basis for setting a behavioral baseline. D is incorrect because it only refers to frequency, not magnitude and duration.

Behavioral rehearsal is similar to role playing. First the therapist describes or demonstrates the desired behavior. Then the client practices what has been taught. Then the client is provided with feedback and reward for desired behaviors. Extinction may occur, as with any learned behavior, but it is not part of the behavioral rehearsal procedure.

The same principles of both operant and respondent learning apply to thoughts as they do to behavior. A is incorrect because psychoactive medications may alter one's thoughts, but they are not usually directly used as part of the cognitive therapy process. C is incorrect because, although operant conditioning may be used, it is only one of many techniques. B is a better answer because it is more inclusive. D is incorrect because, although reward is used in cognitive behavioral therapy, punishment (or aversive stimuli) may be used as well.

In flooding, the client is presented with stimuli that are associated with anxiety for long periods of time until they lose their capacity to evoke anxiety. A is incorrect because depression due to misconceptions is best treated with cognitive restructuring techniques. C is incorrect because flooding is usually used to eliminate a problematic behavior, including anxiety. Acquiring assertion skills is best accomplished through instructional techniques, modeling and behavioral rehearsal. D is incorrect because the disorientation in a person with delirium is biologically caused and the underlying biological dysfunction needs to be treated medically.

Note the word "except" in the question. Sifneos and Malan, two leading proponents of the psychodynamic approach to brief therapy, state that the therapist must be able to simultaneously provide and balance confrontation and support. They do not call on the therapist to emphasize one over the other. The principles addressed in A, B and D are all key elements in this approach to therapy.

Conditions that might be viewed as mental illness in Western cultures may be viewed as a disharmony between mind, body and spirit in Asian and Pacific Islander cultures. Indigenous healing practices seek to restore this harmony. A is incorrect because self-control and emotional restraint are valued. Use of will power and suppression of disturbing thoughts is likely to be sought, rather than encouraging their catharsis. C is incorrect because a sense of intergenerational dependence tends to be valued, and is not seen as a cause of psychic distress or social dysfunction. D is incorrect because indigenous healers are just as likely to be concerned with relieving distress as with enhancing social functioning.

The requirements stated in answers A, C and D are all clearly stated in the AAMFT Code of Ethics Sec. 7.2. B is the correct answer because you have no formal ethical obligation to justify your fee to the client. The client is free to accept or reject the fee.

Improved efficiency means obtaining better results for less expenditure of energy. B is incorrect because psychic energy which is invested in either conflicts or fixations is inefficiently directed away from obtaining gratification in the real world. C is incorrect because Psychodynamic Psychotherapy may seek to bring preconscious material into consciousness, but this is not directly related to the concept of improved efficiency. D is incorrect because the concept of "improved efficiency" refers to a much broader array of issues than rapid development of a therapeutic alliance. This is only one example of how psychic energy might be efficiently invested.

A is incorrect because your client would simply claim that your notes were inaccurate. Also, it is likely that the treatment relationship would not be enhanced at a time like this by reminding the client that you are writing notes about them after every session. C is incorrect because it is not a genuine response. D is incorrect because the interpretation would not be very effective at this point in time while the client is denying that she is being deceptive. B is genuine without being overbearing on the client.

Closed questions and requests for descriptions tend to result in better focused answers. Open ended questions and requests for speculation, inferences and impressions tend to result in less focused answers. They are useful for engaging clients in deeper self-exploration but not for focus. A is an open ended question. B is an indirect question because it begs the same kind of response as an open ended question would. D is an even more broadly worded question than A. C is a more specific, and therefore delimited, request for a description of a day at work.

After "disputing" the client's false beliefs through rational confrontation, homework assignments are used to break negative behavior patterns and self-reinforcement is taught through learning covert self-statements, more constructive statements that clients learn to make to themselves. B is incorrect because, in R.E.T, the therapist disputes the beliefs and confronts the client with their invalidity rather than focusing on the client's need to maintain the belief. C is incorrect because the false beliefs are disputed before new beliefs are offered in their place. D is incorrect because R.E.T. focuses on the way in which thought causes emotions, not the other way around.

Note the word "only" in the question. The Child Abuse Reporting Law states that a marriage and family therapist must report if you have "knowledge of or observe a child in his or her professional capacity or within the scope of his or her employment..." A is incorrect because your reasonable suspicion may be based on information from any source. B is incorrect for the same reason. D is incorrect information obtained in the course of private, personal relationships.

Note the word "except" in the question. The cultural identity of the client's significant others is not specifically addressed by the DSM framework for a Cultural Formulation, and it would be unethical to reveal information that is not needed to accomplish the purpose of the request. In order to determine the cultural identity of others the therapist would need to interview those others. This would be an expensive and cumbersome process. Most of the focus of the Cultural Formulation is on the client's experience of his or her own cultural reference group and what is known about the culture in general.

This approach offers to empower the mother if she is ready to take that step. If not, then the therapist should make the call to protect the daughter and to comply with legal mandates. A is incorrect because it fosters an aura of secrecy and distance between therapist and client. C is incorrect because this action would be too stressful for most nine year olds in this situation and because the therapist doesn't have the authority to insist that the mother make the call. D is incorrect because it fails to offer the mother the opportunity to take a positive action on her daughter's, and her own, behalf.

HIPAA regulations apply to any health care provider who engages in one or more electronic transmissions of private client information. This does not include telephone communications, or communications from one fax machine to another, but it does include communications between a fax machine and a computer. B is incorrect because paper records alone would not qualify a marriage and family therapist as a HIPAA covered entity. C is incorrect because submission of claims to an insurance plan would only qualify the therapist as a covered entity if communications of client information with the insurance plan were made by electronic means. D is incorrect because a single electronic transmission regarding a single client would qualify the therapist as a covered entity, regardless of the total number of clients served.

Curanderos typically have the aim of bringing the individual closer to the spiritual and religious culture of the Roman Catholic church. They do not generally practice exorcism or witchcraft. They do commonly use massage, cupping, "cleansing" rituals, herb remedies, prayer, advice, confession and reassurance.

These three qualities are specifically designed to provide a therapeutic relationship process. They can be offered before a great deal of assessment information has been gathered. B is incorrect because during the first few sessions you don't know the client well enough to offer sound advice or realistic reassurance about the presenting problem. C is incorrect because these techniques will require considerable exposure prematurely. This is often associated with a sense of embarrassment, shame and premature termination. D is incorrect because confrontations and interpretations should generally wait until after a therapeutic alliance is established and the therapist has enough information about the client's personality and life situation to be able to make interpretations accurate, meaningful and well timed.

Biofeedback teaches a person to enhance their own alpha waves which are associated with relaxation. A is incorrect because electroconvulsive therapy, or shock therapy, is used to treat depression. B is incorrect because antabuse is an agonist therapy for treatment of alcoholism. D is incorrect because lithium carbonate is used to treat manic episodes in a bipolar disorder.

Note the word "except" in the question. You should be prepared to increase the frequency of visits or to set ad hoc appointments; also be available by phone and arrange for back up or crisis service contacts available when you are not. All other techniques noted should be used with suicidal clients.

Isolation generally includes any intentional act that serves to separate the individual from others against his or her will. It includes preventing the dependent or elder adult from receiving mail or phone calls, falsely telling prospective visitors that the person is not present, false imprisonment, or physical restraint for the purpose of preventing a meeting with visitors. B is incorrect because it describes "neglect," not "isolation." C is incorrect because quarantine performed pursuant to a physician's instructions is explicitly excluded from the law regarding isolation. D is incorrect because physical restraint for the purpose of punishment is "physical abuse," not "isolation." See Sections 1510.43 through 1510.63 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code.

These theories prescribe such experiences as self- congruence and empathic understanding. They speak of "implementation of an attitude" rather than specific techniques. A is incorrect because these approaches deemphasize treatment planning and prescribe no particular planning techniques. C is incorrect because, again, the focus is what attitude a therapist should assume, not what a therapist should do in a procedural sense. D is incorrect because the Humanistic Existential therapist does not interpret a client's dreams, as a psychoanalytic therapist might do.

Note the words "all but one" in the question. Gestalt Therapy is focused on experience, not intellectual analysis. A is incorrect because acceptance of responsibility is a core value in that it contributes to developing a sense of integrity or wholeness. B is incorrect because risk taking is a core value. It refers to letting go of archaic response patterns and allowing new ones to emerge in the present circumstances. D is incorrect because this principle is a core value in all Humanistic Existential psychotherapies, including Gestalt.

Ambiguous and covert promises are dysfunctional communication patterns which would arouse frustration, anger and rebellion in most people. These are not considered transference reactions because they are not based on distortions brought to the current relationship by the client as a result of past experiences with others. B is incorrect because advice and direction are not a standard practice in many approaches to psychotherapy. If the client has sought psychotherapy and if these limitations are clearly explained to the client during early sessions, rebellion against this limitation would be an unrealistic transference. C and D are incorrect for the same reason that B is incorrect. They reflect standard psychotherapy practices which the client is free to accept or reject by terminating the psychotherapy relationship.

Many people confuse "negative reinforcement" with punishment. Negative reinforcement creates a positive experience for the individual by removing something that had previously been aversive, annoying, or painful. For example, if a child has been confined to his room until he finishes his homework, by allowing the child to leave his room when homework is finished he has been negatively I reinforced. Eliminating a previously imposed punishment constitutes negative reenforcement. B is incorrect because it describes punishment, not negative reinforcement. C is incorrect for reasons noted above. D is incorrect because anticipatory guidance involves instruction and rational discussion, not specifically reinforcement.

When conducting a mental status exam, calculation questions test a person's ability to concentrate and focus attention through the steps of the calculation. But the client's fund of information is being tested as well. If a client had never learned how to divide, good concentration and attention span will not produce the correct answer. That's why B is incorrect. C is incorrect because level of consciousness refers to a person's capacity to focus and shift, as well as maintain attention. A client's degree of alertness and wakefulness should be apparent from simple interview questions and would not require a calculation test. D is incorrect because recent memory refers to a person's ability to recall information over a period of several hours to several days. Tests of calculation require use of memory, primarily immediate retention and recall, not recent memory.

A is incorrect because "oriented times three" refers to a person's orientation at a point in time, not over the course of time. B is incorrect because orientation to procedure is not an aspect of the mental status exam. A person may be asked to follow a set of procedures, such as arranging matchsticks in a particular geometric pattern, but this is a test for apraxia or disturbed executive function, not orientation. D is incorrect because, although these are mental status exam issues, they are not matters of orientation.

This awkwardly worded requirement is found in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 5328 which governs confidentiality in public mental health service systems. The law states that information and records shall be disclosed only in certain situations. Among them is this. "In communications between qualified professional persons in the provision of services or appropriate referrals, or in the course of conservatorship proceedings." The law then places a restriction on communications between certain professional persons. The consent of the patient, or his or her guardian or conservator shall be obtained before information or records may be disclosed by a professional person employed by a facility to a professional person not employed by the facility who does not have the medical or psychological responsibility for the patient's care? A and B are incorrect because the law allows sharing of confidential information among staff of a program and even staff of a service system, as long as the client is informed at the outset of treatment that such sharing of information is the practice. D is incorrect because information may be shared, even without the client's consent, when the receiving person has medical or psychological responsibility for the client. The clients consent must be obtained before sharing information with others who do not have medical or psychological responsibility for the client.

Presence means that goals should be stated in the affirmative, indicating what should be present when the goal is achieved. Feeling relaxed is what is present when anxiety is reduced. B is incorrect because both "increase confidence" and "improve self esteem" are examples of presence. C is incorrect because both "improve social skills" and "improve quality of social relationships" are also examples of presence. D is incorrect because "reduce anxiety" is an example of absence, not presence. Also, "increase self-assertion skills" is an example of presence, not absence.

Thought recording is a technique used for identifying automatic thoughts. These thoughts must first be identified before the evidence for their validity can be examined (B), or before alternatives can be generated (A). C is incorrect because reattribution is also an intervention technique used to correct erroneous attributions of cause-effect relationships.

The Welfare and Institutions Code Sec. 5328 states that confidential information shall be disclosed only under certain conditions. Among them is this. "When the patient, with the approval of the...licensed marriage and family therapist, who is in charge of the patient, designates persons to whom information or records may be released, except that nothing in this article shall be construed to compel a...licensed marriage and family therapist...or other professional person to reveal information that has been given to him or her in confidence by members of a patient's family." A is incorrect because most public mental health clients are clinically and legally competent to give informed consent, and approval by a family member is not necessary. C is incorrect because the therapist may release the information but is not compelled to do so. Clients often give consent to release more information than is necessary to release in order to accomplish the clients own purpose. D is incorrect because most clients are presumed to be competent. A formal documented evaluation is not required every time the client gives consent, unless there are indicators that the individual might not be competent.

Cathexis refers to the way in which psychic energy becomes invested in a particular object or issue. A fixation is a cathexis that remains long after there is any adaptive purpose to the investment of psychic energy. A is incorrect because secondary process thinking refers to logical and reality oriented thinking. B is incorrect because psychic structure refers to the id, ego and superego. A fixation is not a structure but a process. D is incorrect because the superego is the aspect of the mind concerned with conscience or morality as it was learned in childhood. Fixations may or may not become established due to morality concerns.

Dis-identification from all that is not the authentic self means giving up the distortions of defensiveness and false identifications with fragmented or partial aspects of self. A is incorrect because repression of the sublime refers to the failure to accept and manifest our highest nature. It is something to be overcome, not to be achieved in therapy. C is incorrect because the concept of mobile fixations is an inherently contradictory combination of concepts from Psychodynamic Theory. D is incorrect because unconditional positive regard is a quality the therapist must bring to the therapeutic process. It is not necessarily a goal for the client to achieve.

Note the words "should not" in the question. The therapist should genuinely accept the unique and special quality and benefits of a crisis intervention approach. A is incorrect because a client's defenses generally should be accepted and supported, not challenged, in crisis intervention therapy, as long as they serve to contain anxiety without disabling the client. B is incorrect because crisis intervention does not seek to achieve fundamental personality change or elimination of clinical syndromes. The focus is on restoring functioning to the precrisis level. C is incorrect because crisis intervention does seek to develop a cognitive grasp of what otherwise might feel like an overwhelming situation. This is done by helping a client to partialize and prioritize elements of the crisis.

Section 11167 of the California Penal Code requires that the mandated reporter provide information about "the name, address, telephone number, and other relevant personal information about the person or persons who might have abused or neglected the child", if known. A is incorrect because the law requires you to report "the child's name, the child's address, present location, and, if applicable, school, grade, and class" but not the child's diagnosis. B is incorrect because reporting requirements apply to the individual reporter, and the reporter's supervisor is irrelevant to the child protective agency. D is incorrect because the reporting law says nothing about the reporter's license number.

Note the word "except" in the question. California law states that "abuse of an elder or a dependent adult" means physical abuse, neglect, fiduciary abuse, abandonment, isolation ,abduction, or other treatment with resulting physical harm or pain or mental suffering..." A, B and C are incorrect because they are specifically mentioned in the law. D, fraud, is not included. Even though fraud may be illegal according to other laws, it is not specifically illegal as elder abuse. Fraud may be similar to "fiduciary abuse." However, fiduciary abuse specifically refers to a situation in which a person who has care or custody of the elder takes, secretes, or appropriates their money or property to any use not in the due and lawful execution of his or her trust. Fiduciary abuse also refers to a situation in which an elder requests that a third party transfer to the elder property which belongs to the elder, but that third party fails to take reasonable steps to make the property readily available.

Olfactory hallucinations are hallucinations involving the sense of smell. These are commonly caused by organic factors, such as brain tumor or presence of toxic substances in the body. B is incorrect because auditory hallucinations can be caused by organic factors, but are much less likely to be organically caused than are olfactory hallucinations. C is incorrect because excessive guilt is much more likely to be caused by dysfunctional cognitions or psychodynamics such as fixations or unresolved conflicts. D is incorrect because illusions are common. They are not psychotic symptoms and can occur as a result of stress, anxiety, or physical exhaustion.

The Business and Professions Code lists the following a unprofessional conduct for which an MFT license can be revoked or suspended. "Reproduction or description in public, or in any publication subject to general public distribution, of any psychological test or other assessment device, the value of which depends in whole or in part on the naivete of the subject, in ways that might invalidate the test or device? If a client was given a copy of MMPI questions outside of a legitimate administration of that test, the value of the test would be compromised when the test is taken by the client or by anyone with whom the client shares the information. A is incorrect because there is no prohibition against referring clients to another professional, even if the referring party would have been qualified to provide the service. For example, an MFT might refer the husband to a colleague for individual therapy when the MFT is seeing the husband and wife as a couple. C is incorrect because MFT's may provide clients with printed information regarding various aspects of physical health, nutrition, or medication, for example. D is incorrect because there is no requirement that all clients be given written information regarding this matter. The BBS has a publication entitled "Professional Therapy Never Involves Sex" which must be given to any client who indicates that they have been sexually assaulted or harassed by a former therapist, but that is not the situation referenced in answer D.

A is incorrect because clients presenting with mental disorders such as compulsive gambling, adjustment disorders, dependent personality disorder and many others are not particularly in need of medications. C is incorrect because, although medication evaluations should generally be made in cases of major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder, they do not necessarily need to be made in many cases of adjustment disorder with depressed mood or dysthymia. D is incorrect because psychomotor retardation per se does not require medications. It is a symptom that even normal, non-diagnosable individuals might experience when physically exhausted from overwork. Sleep, rest and relaxation are sufficient in most cases without medications.

By being clear and focused as to the purpose of your referral, the client and the person receiving the referral can approach the matter efficiently and avoid unnecessary role confusion. B is incorrect because such a request would be inefficient. For example, it could lead the physician to evaluate for conditions already known to have been ruled out. C is incorrect because it is inefficient and because the client may not fully understand why the referral is needed. Also, the client may want to raise other issues with the professional receiving the referral, and the professional will need to know which issues are of concern to you and should be reported back to you, and which may be of concern to the client but irrelevant to the client's work with you. D is incorrect because the person receiving the referral does not need to know about your limitations. He or she only needs to know about the client and the client oriented purpose of the referral.

Flight into health often develops during the first few sessions, in part due to positive transference or magical thinking about the therapist's ability to cause a cure. A is incorrect because the anticipation of termination is more likely to trigger a regression as the client makes a bid to keep the therapeutic relationship going by maintaining a need for it. B is incorrect because just prior to beginning therapy the client is much more likely to be focusing on the problem and his or her inability to solve it without help. D is incorrect because during the middle phase the client's initial fantasies and magical thinking about cure have been dashed through experience. Nothing magical has happened after all. The client may feel disappointed and experience a return of symptoms that have been suppressed, repressed, or otherwise set aside during the initial phase flight into health.

A is incorrect because such self-exploration of themes tends to exacerbate internal preoccupation and is likely to be ineffective. B is incorrect because such confrontation is likely to alienate the client and is likely to be ineffective. D is incorrect because, although it may be helpful for the person with schizophrenia to become familiar with the nature of his or her symptoms, the causes of schizophrenia are not yet fully understood by science and will not be of great practical value in the client's daily living. C is a better answer because it is relevant to supporting the client's quality of life, and because medication compliance will probably be the most effective possible approach to reducing the client's multiple delusions and other problematic symptoms.

Self-alienation refers to a kind of phobic avoidance of parts of ourselves. To the extent that we keep certain needs, feelings, and desires out of awareness we become alienated from ourselves. A part of ourselves is left in the background  our "unfinished business" while we go about tending to the presumably less threatening issues or diversions that we permit into consciousness. Personal integration involves an openness to the full range of our true experience, however unpleasant that may be. The result is personal effectiveness and a more confident sense of presence and integrity. B is incorrect because this describes the general direction of Crisis Intervention Therapy. C is incorrect because Humanistic Existential Psychotherapy moves toward accepting our ambivalences, not overcoming them. The goal is not self certainty and relaxation, but a sense of self acceptance and presence, even in the face of the inevitable self doubts and tensions that arise in our lives. D is incorrect because this is a more apt description of the general direction in Psychodynamic Psychotherapy.

This issue is addressed in AAMFT Code of Ethics Sec. 3.14 which states "To avoid a conflict of interests, marriage and family therapists who treat minors or adults involved in custody or visitation actions may not also perform forensic evaluations for custody, residence, or visitation of the minor." A is incorrect because the same section of the Code of Ethics clearly states that the treating marriage and family therapist "may provide the court or mental health professional performing the evaluation with information about the minor from the marriage and family therapist's perspective as a treating marriage and family therapist, so long as the marriage and family therapist does not violate confidentiality." C and D are incorrect because performance of such forensic evaluations is prohibited by the Code of Ethics.

Automatic thoughts are more readily apparent to an individual and, therefore, should be addressed first. B is incorrect because core beliefs are deeper cognitions, or fundamental assumptions behind our automatic thoughts. They therefore will take longer to access, if they are to be addressed at all in therapy. C and D are incorrect because "adaptive schemas" and "maladaptive schemas" are types of core beliefs.

Cognitive empiricism refers to the collaborative, reality focused way in which the therapist and client function as an investigative team. Hypotheses are developed and their validity is tested through rational analysis and empirical experimentation to discover "does this really make sense?" A is incorrect because it is impossible to refrain from feeling or showing emotion, and because the Cognitive Therapy literature values the use of humor with those clients who respond well to it. C is incorrect because the focus should be on the clients' cognitions here and now, not over time. These present cognitions should be understood in the context of the client's long term growth and development, but most people are unable to clearly remember automatic thoughts from the past. D is incorrect because Cognitive Therapy discourages dependency and regression, while encouraging active participation by the client. This may be done, for example, through the use of self monitoring and self help techniques and homework assignments.

B is incorrect because the DRDT focuses on the individual's own automatic thoughts and his or her own emotional reaction to those thoughts. The DRDT includes a list of circumstances that trigger automatic thoughts, but does not include other people's reactions following the thoughts. Usually, other people don't know when a person is having an automatic thought. C is incorrect because the DRDT includes a list of the client's own more rational, realistic or functional thoughts, not the therapist's. D is incorrect because the only listing of circumstances refers to those that trigger the automatic thought, not those that trigger relaxation or anxiety reduction. That issue is more likely to be addressed in a Behavioral Therapy process of systematic desensitization.

Humanistic Existential Therapies recognize that circumstances influence individuals, but that we each make choices about what we will do with our circumstances. A is incorrect because the focus is on the individuals will and free choice, not on social determinants of one's behavior. The social environment is recognized and understood, but is not the focus of the therapy. B is incorrect because lack of opportunity is one aspect of the social environment. D is incorrect because Humanistic Existential Therapies emphasize experience and self-exploration rather than rational analysis of ones ideas and beliefs. Also, adaptive schemas are a concept drawn from Cognitive Therapy, not in Humanistic Existential Therapy.

Through this technique, primarily associated with Gestalt Therapy, the client engages in self-revelation and self-exploration with the eventual goal of self-integration. A is incorrect because, although playful use of imagination may be adaptive under certain circumstances, it is not the basis for this technique. Also, the use of imagination in this technique is not viewed as inherently healing, but as a means to the end of self-exploration and self-integration. B is incorrect because the holy trinity is a Christian concept which is not accepted by all Humanistic Existential therapists. Although Humanistic Existential Therapies do tend to address spiritual issues, this is usually done in a secular or nonsectarian manner. D is incorrect because taking the role of other dream elements allows us to see ourselves as we truly do at deeper levels of consciousness. It is not designed to allow us to see ourselves as others see us.
